chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we need to solve for the average real return and the average nominal risk premium for the stocks of this company.

**a.** The real return refers to the inflation-adjusted rate of return on the company's stock. This can be solved by taking the average rate of return then subtracting it with the value of the inflation rate.

Solving for the average nominal rate of return, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{average nominal rate}&=\dfrac{8-15+19+31+21}{5}\\[15 pt]
&=12.8
\end{aligned}$$

Subtract the average nominal rate by the inflation rate to get the average real rate of return.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{average real rate}&=12.8-3.1\\[15 pt]
&=9.7
\end{aligned}$$

The average real rate of return is $9.7\%$

**b.** The average nominal risk premium refers to the difference between the risk-free investment and a risky investment. In this case, the risk-free investment is the treasury bills. We can get the average nominal risk premium by subtracting the average nominal return of the t-bills from the average nominal return of the stock.

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{average nominal risk premium}&=12.8\%-3.9\%\\[15 pt]
&=8.9\%
\end{aligned}$$

The average nominal risk premium is $8.9\%$
